p: The SARS-CoV genome was the first to be described in 2002, with approximately 29.7 kb in length, followed by MERS-CoV in 2012, with 30.1 kb and the SARS-CoV genome in 2019, with 29.8 kb [ [28], [29], [30], [31]], including a variable number (from 6 to 14) of open reading frames (ORFs) [ 32]. The first ORF represents approximately 67 % of the entire genome, encoding 16 non-structural proteins (nsps), translated by genomic RNA. While the other ORFs encode accessory and structural proteins, translated by 10 subgenomic RNAs [ [33], [34], [35], [36], [37]].
